Review Sulfonic acid-functionalized mesoporous silica (SBA-Pr-SO3H) as solid acid catalyst in organic reactions Ghodsi Mohammadi Ziarani a ⁎ Negar Lashgari b Alireza Badiei b a Department of Chemistry, Alzahra University, Vanak Square, P.O. Box 14155-6455, Tehran, Iran School of Chemistry, College of Science, University of Tehran P.O. Box 14155-6455 Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 2188041344; fax: +98 2188041344. Graphical abstract Mesoporous silica SBA-15 has been functionalized with sulfonic acid to create highly powerful heterogeneous solid acid catalysts (SBA-Pr-SO3H). The catalyst can be easily removed from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, recovered and reused without significant loss of activity. In this review, the catalytic activity of sulfonic acid-functionalized SBA-15 has been widely studied. Keywords Mesoporous materials Catalysts Silica Sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 1 Introduction Synthesis of chemical products of great industrial importance often leads to the use of mineral acids as homogeneous catalysts. This type of synthesis presents as main drawback, the generation of considerable amounts of toxic residues. Consequently, in recent years there has been developed a great interest in the replacement of the conventional homogeneous acid catalysts by heterogeneous acid catalysts, because of the possibility for recovering and recycling the solids, and therefore significantly reducing the environmental impact. Since the discovery of M41S mesoporous silica by the Mobil oil company in 1992 [1], there is a rapid growth in research and development of mesoporous materials. In this regard, mesoporous silica materials have generated much interest as a catalyst support in heterogeneous catalysis because of their high specific surface area, ordered mesoporous structure, and large pore volume. In this context, SBA-15, introduced by Stucky and co-workers [2], is a kind of mesoporous silica featured by a well-ordered hexagonal structure, large pore size, high surface area, and high thermal stability, can conveniently include functional groups into its mesoporous framework by grafting or co-condensation to create efficient solid catalysts with improved catalytic properties as compared to conventional homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. These functionalized hybrid materials are characterized by the combination of properties that can be tuned using different conformations of their organic and inorganic structures. Due to these features hybrid materials are particularly desirable in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. In addition to their use in catalytic processes, functionalized SBA-15 materials have been increasingly used as adsorbents [3–8], sensors [9–11], and carrier materials in drug delivery [12–15]. The internal surface of SBA-15 has been successfully modified by different organic functionalities such as amine [16], proline and aminopropyl [17], biguanide [18], 8-hydroxyquinoline [19], nitroxyl radical 2,2,6,6,-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) with 1-methyl-3-butylimidazolium (BMImBr) ionic liquid [20], N-methyl-N′-propyl imidazolium chloride [21], 1-methyl-3-octylimidazolium hydrogensulfate ionic liquid [OMIm]HSO4 [22], phosphoric acid [23], carboxylic acid [24,25], cationic Ru(III) complex and anionic sulfonate [26], 4-(2-chloroacetyl)-3-methyl-1-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-5(4H)-one (H-AP) or 5-chloromethyl-8-quinolinol hydrochloride (H-HQ) as potential proligands for the preparation of anchored oxovanadium(IV) complexes [27], isocyanate [28], and amino acids (Fig. 1 ) [29]. In this context, mesoporous materials containing sulfonic groups which combine a relatively high acid strength with a large surface area and reactant accessibility, are promising acid catalysts. A number of reviews deal with the functionalization of mesostructured silicates with organic surface groups [30–33]. In 2006, Melero and co-workers reviewed the synthesis and application of novel acid catalysts based on sulfonic-modified mesostructured materials [34]. In this review we describe the synthesis and application of these sulfonic-modified mesostructured materials in organic reactions. 2 Preparation and characterization of sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-Pr-SO3H) Basically, two strategies have been described to anchor organic groups to a mesostructured silica surface via formation of covalent bonds: grafting methods (post-synthesis procedure) and co-condensation reactions (direct synthesis) [35,36]. Grafting procedures are based on modification of the silica surface with organic groups through silylation reactions occurring on isolated and germinal silanol groups using trichloro- or trialkoxyorganosilane and silylamines as organic precursors. In contrast, direct synthesis consists of the co-condensation of siloxane and organosiloxane precursors in the presence of the corresponding structure-directing agent, SDA [34]. Each functionalization pathway has certain advantages. Post-synthesis modification (grafting) that involves synthesizing SBA-15 silica materials followed by subsequent surface functionalization allows the synthesis of modified SBA-15 with highly ordered silica geometries even at moderately high acid loadings to create good solid acid catalysts [37,38]. In addition, novel mesoporous materials having functional groups in framework wall, periodic mesoporous organosilicates (PMO), have been also paid much attention in recent years [39–41]. A number of PMO applications will be briefly pointed out, although this is not the main aim of this review. A schematic illustration for the preparation of SBA-Pr-SO3H was shown in Fig. 2 . First, the calcined SBA-15 silica was functionalized with (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (MPTS) and then, the thiol groups were oxidized to sulfonic acid by hydrogen peroxide. The catalyst surface can be analyzed by different methods such as Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and CHN methods. The texture properties of SBA-15 and sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 are given in Table 1 . The surface area, average pore diameter calculated by the BET method and pore volume of SBA-Pr-SO3H are smaller than those of SBA-15 due to the immobilization of sulfonosilane groups into the pores [42]. The TGA analysis of SBA-Pr-SO3H (Fig. 3 ) confirmed the amount of organic groups on SBA-15. The weight reduction of SBA-Pr-SO3H in the temperature range between 200 and 600°C indicated that the amount of organic group was 1.2mmolg−1. Also, the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms for SBA-15 and SBA-Pr-SO3H (Fig. 4 ) suggest that the prepared samples have regular mesoporous framework structures [42]. 3 Application of SBA-Pr-SO3H in organic transformations 3.1 Esterification reactions The esterification reaction can be catalyzed by either alkalis or mineral acids. However, alkali catalysts usually have slower reaction rates than acidic catalysts together with soap formation as a by-product [43]. Industrially, strong liquid acids, such as H2SO4, HCl and para-toluenesulfonic acid, are used as the esterification catalysts but they have traditional drawbacks such as equipment corrosion, hazards in handling, difficult separation from the products, and production of toxic waste. As a matter of fact, the use of heterogeneous acid catalysts in these reactions could vastly simplify catalyst removal, reduce catalyst cost, and minimize the amount of waste formed. Solid acid catalysts used in esterification and transesterification reactions include zeolites [44], resins [45–48], supported heteropolyacids [49–51], sulfated metal oxides [52–56], and sulfonated carbon [57,58]. However, despite promising improvements, several drawbacks for these chemicals include the leaching of the active sites, thermal stability, and low surface area and pore size. In this regard, sulfonic acid functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 materials could be an interesting alternative. SBA-15 containing sulfonic groups was tested as acid catalyst in the esterification of free fatty acids with methanol [59–62]. For example, esterification of caprylic acid with ethanol [63], glycerol with oleic acid [64], glycerol with lauric acid toward monoglyceride [65–67], levulinic acid with different alcohols [68], and acetic acid with methanol [69,70] were carried out in the presence of acid catalysts SBA-15-Ph-SO3H and SBA-15-Pr-SO3H respectively. The fact that these materials are active for these reactions indicates that they have strong acidity. It was found that the activity of sulfonic acid hybrid silica used as catalysts for transesterification reactions depended on the morphology of the silica and also on the preparation procedure [71]. In a further study, it was demonstrate that SBA-15-SO3H is a potential catalyst for the direct addition esterification of acrylic acid with cyclohexene. The unique structure and suitable acid nature of SBA-15-SO3H were considered to be response to the efficient catalytic performance [72]. The catalytic performance of the p-styrenesulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 (PSS/SBA-15) was also tested in the esterification of lauric acid with ethanol at ambient atmosphere [73]. The unique catalytic performance of PSS-SBA-15 is probably attributed to the increased accessibility of the active sites to the reactants because of the existence of styrenesulfonic acid on the pore surface of SBA-15. Corma and co-workers presented the preparation of hybrid SBA-15 silica functionalized with terminal perfluoroalkylsulfonic acid groups in a single step by reacting the mesoporous silicas with 1,2,2-trifluoro-2-hydroxy-1-trifluoromethylethane sulfonic acid β-sultone. The catalyst showed higher activity for esterification of octanoic acid with ethanol than Nafion® [74]. It was also reported that the catalyst can be reused repeatedly without any observed loss of activity. The hybrid poly(styrenesulfonic acid)-modified SBA-15 showed good catalytic activities in the esterification of oleic acid with n-butanol, particularly in terms of intrinsic activity per acid site [75]. In a similar way, the catalytic activity of different ordered mesoporous silicas functionalized with propylsulfonic acid groups was tested over the esterification reaction of acetic acid with n-butanol to produce 1-butylacetate [76]. The effects of mesophase and functionalization technique were related to the catalytic performance. The higher functionalization was reached by co-condensation technique, and the best ratio between catalytic performance and functionalization degree was exhibited by SBA-15, followed by MCM-41, HMS and MCM-48 in decreasing order. Substantial differences in catalytic activity were found for materials with hexagonal and cubic mesophase. Sulfonic acid-functionalized mesostructured SBA-15 silicas (Pr-SBA-15 and Ar-SBA-15) have been demonstrated to be active for the catalytic transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate to produce di- and triacetylglycerols [77]. An optimization of the reaction conditions carried out with pharmaceutical glycerol by means of experimental design methodology showed that it is necessary to use a high methyl acetate to glycerol molar ratio (50:1) and a high catalyst loading (7.5wt% based on glycerol) in order to obtain simultaneously very high glycerol conversion (99.5%) and high combined selectivity toward di- and triacetylglycerols (74.2%). In addition, the formation of non-desired byproduct was minimized at such reaction conditions. In an interesting study, a series of SBA-15 containing different amounts of sulfonic acid bearing groups by using various contents of 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane (MPTMS) in the range of 5–20% were used as solid acid catalysts in the esterification of salicylic acid with dimethyl carbonate [78]. According to the data in Table 2 , the conversion of salicylic acid over the sulfonic acid functionalized materials as catalysts was found to increase with the increase in reaction time. By using SBA-15-SO3H-20 as catalyst, the complete conversion (98.09%) and the selectivity toward methyl salicylate (96.21%) were achieved after 8h of run at 473K. Direct esterification of alcohols and carboxylic acids in the presence of SBA-15-Pr-SO3H at ambient temperature under solvent-free conditions has been reported by Karimi and Vafaeezadeh [79]. The catalyst comprises of a hydrophobic task-specific ionic liquid 1-methyl-3-octylimidazolium hydrogen sulfate [MOIm][HSO4] charged in close proximity of anchored sulfonic acid groups in the interior of nanospaces of ordered mesoporous silica SBA-15 leading to a super Brønsted acid solid catalyst. In another study, Karimi and co-workers employed periodic mesoporous organosilicas (PMOs) having either phenylene or ethyl as bridge and methylpropyl sulfonic acid as functionalized group in biodiesel production [80]. In this study, direct transesterification of sunflower oil, canola oil, corn oil, refined olive oil, and extracted oil from olive sludge with methanol has been reported. By comparing the catalytic performance of these acids with well-known SBA-15-Pr-SO3H, it was revealed that the catalyst bearing an ethyl bridging group is a more reactive catalytic system in biodiesel production. It was also shown that the recovered catalyst can be effectively used for three successive cycles. The transesterification of crude Jatropha oil with methanol over sulfonic acid-functionalized platelet SBA-15 mesoporous silica in both batch-type and fixed-bed reaction systems was examined [81]. It showed higher activity and resistances to water and free fatty acid than commercial sulfonic resins of Amberlyst-15 and SAC-13. Biodiesel synthesis through esterification of free fatty acids and transesterification of triglycerides with methanol, in the presence of sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 as the catalyst was extensively investigated by Melero's group [82–86]. The catalytic results showed that sulfonic acid-modified mesostructured materials were more active than conventional ion-exchange sulfonic resins (Amberlyst-36 and Nafion®–SiO2 composite) (Chart 1 ). The reusability of the catalysts was also investigated showing high stability for propyl-SO3H and arene-SO3H-modified mesostructured materials. The impact of pore diameter on the catalytic activity of sulfonic acid functionalized, pore-expanded SBA materials toward palmitic acid esterification, and the transesterification of tricaprylin and triolein was also studied [87]. Pore expansion over the range 6–14nm confers a striking activity enhancement attributed to improved mass transport and acid site accessibility. In a related study, mesostructured SBA-15 catalysts functionalized by different sulfonic acid groups (propyl-SO3H, arene-SO3H, and perfluoro-SO3H) have been synthesized and studied in the microwave-assisted transesterification of soybean oil with 1-butanol in order to produce low freezing point biodiesel [88]. Catalytic activity was found to be largely dependent on the acid strength rather than the number of acid sites. Propyl-SO3H and arene-SO3H functionalized SBA-15 catalysts showed high activity and stability in transesterification reactions whereas perfluoro-SO3H functionalized SBA-15 catalyst exhibited a complete loss of activity after recycling due to complete leaching of perfluoro-SO3H groups in the reaction medium. 3.2 Etherification reactions During biodiesel production, by transesterification of vegetable oils with methanol, glycerol is formed as by-product in high amounts. Isobutylene reacts with glycerol in the presence of acid catalysts to yield a mixture of mono-, di-, and tri-tert-butyl glycerol ethers. This reaction has been usually performed over sulfonic resins [89,90] and homogenous acid catalysts. Usually, low surface areas and lack of thermal stability are the major drawbacks of sulfonic resins. On the other hand, the use of conventional homogenous acid catalysts must be avoided to comply with the increasingly strict environmental regulations. Etherification of glycerol with isobutylene to obtain selective di- and tri-tertiary butyl ethers, the so-called high ethers (h-GTBE) was tested in the presence of microwave-assisted sulfonated SBA-15 [91] and propylsulfonic acid-modified mesostructured silica, Pr-SBA-15 [92]. It was observed that the activities and selectivities achieved over sulfonic acid-functionalized mesostructured silicas are comparable or even superior to those displayed by widely used macroporous commercial acid resins. Propyl- and arene-SO3H-modified mesostructured SBA-15 materials have been shown as active catalysts in the preparation of benzyl ethers from benzyl alcohols [93]. Despite their lower acid strength, propyl-SO3H acid sites provide higher activity than arene-SO3H groups as a consequence of the lower hydrophilicity of the sulfonic acid site microenvironment of the former which reduces the poisoning effect by water molecules. In another study, a series of sulfonated mesoporous silica and organosilica was investigated as catalyst in direct production of dibutyl ether from 1-butanol [94]. Good catalytic activity and high conversion was observed for all catalysts which include sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15, arenesulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 and arenesulfonic acid functionalized mesostructured ethane silica which the latter showed the highest 1-butanol conversion (80%) compared to all other catalysts tested. A propylsulfonic acid-derivatized mesoporous SBA-15 catalyst was examined for activity and selectivity in the dehydrocondensation of methanol and isobutanol to form ethers, principally methyl isobutyl ether (MIBE) and dimethyl ether (DME) [95,96]. Kinetic analysis was consistent with competitive adsorption of the two alcohols onto Brønsted acid sites, with isobutanol being more strongly adsorbed on the acid sites than the methanol. 3.3 Dehydration reactions The conversion of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is an important model reaction in carbohydrate chemistry. Selective dehydration of fructose 1 to HMF 6 was reported in the presence of silica-supported alkylsulfonic acids [97,98] and bifunctional silicas containing a propylsulfonic acid catalyst and a thioether group (Scheme 1 ) [99]. Using ionic liquid BmimCl as a solvent in this reaction was also investigated [100]. In a similar study, sulfonic acid-modified mesoporous SBA-15-type silica and hybrid organosilica catalysts were prepared using the co-condensation and grafting functionalization methods and the catalytic activity of these materials for fructose dehydration to HMF was studied in aqueous medium and in DMSO [101]. Among the materials tested, the hybrid organosilica-based catalyst shows the highest dehydration rate. The application of a number of mesoporous sulfonic acids including SBA-15-PrSO3H, SBA-15-Ph-PrSO3H, SBA-15-EtPhSO3H, and SBA-15-Ph-EtPhSO3H with different surface hydrophobicity in this reaction was also investigated by Karimi and Mirzaei [102]. Among the studied mesoporous solid acids, the catalyst with lower surface hydrophobicity and relative acidity were found to be more selective and efficient catalytic system for HMF production. HMF selectivity of 75% was reached in 93% fructose conversion in water/nitromethane system at 140°C within 30min in the presence of SBA-15-PrSO3H catalyst which is comparable or even superior to the other systems. In a related study, investigations by Saravanamurugan and Riisager have shown that SO3H-SBA-15 is an efficient catalyst in the selective conversion of fructose 1 to ethyl levulinate (57%) 11 and glucose 8 to ethyl-D-glucopyranoside (EDGP) (80%) 9 at 140°C (Scheme 2 ) [103].Catalytic activity of organo-functionalized mesoporous silicas SBA-15 with sulfonic acid (SBA-15-SO3H) was evaluated for the dehydration of xylose 12 to furfural 13 (Scheme 3 ) [104]. The deactivation and regeneration of the SBA-15-SO3H catalyst was also investigated. The results indicate that the used and regenerated catalysts retained the SBA-15 mesoporous structure. In another study, Agirrezabal-Telleria and co-workers have discovered that pore size tuning of functionalized SBA-15 catalysts resulted in the selective production of furfural from xylose [105]. Application of sulfonic acid-functionalized mesoporous silicas (SBA-15) as catalysts in the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol 14 at moderate temperature was reported by Lourenco and co-workers [106]. Formation of the main dehydration products from glycerol has been shown in Scheme 4 . For the tested conditions all the samples show a very high catalytic activity. It was concluded that both the pore size and density of acid sites play an important role in the deactivation rate and selectivity: larger pore size may extend significantly the catalytic activity and high density of acid sites may reduce acrolein 16 production. A variety of α,β-substituted nitroalcohols 18 were converted to their corresponding nitro-olefins 19 under mild reaction conditions using 3-propylsulfonic acid-functionalized SBA-15 (Scheme 5 ) [107]. SO3H-SBA-15 was found to be more efficient catalyst than microporous zeolites under similar reaction conditions. The reusability of SO3H-SBA-15 was also checked for three repetitive reaction cycles. The catalyst was successfully activated and the activity was decreased marginally to 93.8% after three successive uses. Sulfonic acid functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 silica was found to be highly efficient and versatile solid acid catalyst for the synthesis of chromenes 21 from chromanols 20 under heterogeneous reaction conditions (Scheme 6 ) [108]. In catalyst recycling experiments, it was found that the solid catalyst is rugged and retains its catalytic performance over the 10 experiments conducted with the same catalyst. 3.4 Oxidation reactions Srinivas and co-workers prepared efficient, chemo- and regioselective mesoporous catalysts for the oxidation of R-(+)-limonene 22. In this regard, SBA-15 molecular sieves were functionalized with propylamine, propylthiol and propylsulfonic acid groups and Mn(Salen)Cl complexes were grafted on these organo-functionalized SBA-15. Oxidation of limonene yields a variety of products including carveol 27 and carvone 28 and 1,2-epoxides 23–24, 8,9-epoxides 25–26 and 1,2 and 8,9-diepoxides (Scheme 7 ) [109–111]. Mn (Salen)Cl supported on propylthiol-functionalized SBA-15 was found to be a superior catalyst for limonene oxidation with aerial oxygen, at ambient conditions, yielding 1,2-limonene epoxide with 100% selectivity. Similarly, the selective oxidation of sulfides 29 to sulfoxides 30 was achieved in excellent yields with SBA-15-Pr-SO3H as a nanoreactor active catalyst and H2O2 as the terminal oxidant (Scheme 8 ) [112]. It was found that the amphiphilic mesochannels of SBA-15 can provide a suitable accommodation for both hydrophilic hydrogen peroxide and hydrophobic sulfides. It also could be recovered and reused for several reaction cycles without considerable loss of reactivity (the average chemical yield for eight consecutive runs was 96%). 3.5 Acetylation and acetoxylation reactions An expeditious method for the acetylation of aldehydes 31 by mesoporous solid sulfonic acid (SBA-15-Ph-Pr-SO3H) under solvent-free reaction conditions was described (Scheme 9 ) [113]. The route furnished selectively and in excellent yields the corresponding 1,1-diacetates 33. The recovered SBA-15-Ph-PrSO3H could be directly reused in nine successive runs without significant loss of activity. This reaction was also performed in the presence of various catalysts including KHSO4 [114], InCl3 [115], solid silica sulfuric acid [116], heterogeneous H3PW12O40 supported MCM-41 molecular sieves [117], Cu(OTf)2 [118], and LiOTf [119]. However, results clearly elucidate that some protocols took much longer time, some used non-recovered catalyst, or some used dangerous materials with reduced isolated yields. The catalytic activity of propylsulfonic acid functionalized nanostructured SBA-15 for acetylation of alcohols and phenols 34 with acetic anhydride 32 at ambient temperature in solvent-free conditions was examined by Zareyee and co-workers (Scheme 10 ) [120]. In another study, acetylation of glycerol with acetic acid at low temperatures in the presence of various types of solid acids, including silica-alumina, dodecamolybdophosphoric acids supported on mesoporous SBA-15 (HPMo/SBA-15), Amberlyst-15, sulfated ceria–zirconia (SCZ), propylsulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 (Pr-SO3H-SBA-15), and sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 (SO3H-SBA-15) was studied by Lee and co-workers [121]. It was observed that the glycerol conversion turnover rate toward di- and triacetin is considerably higher on Pr-SO3H-SBA-15 and Amberlyst-15. The acetoxylation of α-pinene 36 was carried out over SBA-15 with sulfonic acid groups. The products of acetoxylation of α-pinene are acetates (α-terpinyl acetate 37, bornyl acetate 38 and β-fenchyl acetate 39) and hydrocarbons (camphene 40, tricyclene 41, limonene 22, γ-terpinene 42, terpinolene 43 and α-terpinene 44) (Scheme 11 ) [122]. The influence of various reaction parameters, such as temperature, initial concentration of α-pinene and catalyst loading, on the activity of the most active catalyst, was also studied. The conversion increased with the increase of surface area and porous volume of the catalysts, probably due to the increases of α-pinene accessibility to the active sites. Mesoporous ordered silica materials (MCM-41, HMS, and SBS-15) were successfully derivatized with covalently anchored propanesulfonic or benzenesulfonic acid groups applying co-condensation or post-synthesis modification (grafting). The samples exhibited high activities in the production of 2,3,5-trimethylhydroquinone diacetate 47 in high yields in the rearrangement–aromatization of ketoisophorone 45 (Scheme 12 ) [123]. 3.6 Silylation reactions Trimethylsilylation of various alcohols and phenols 34 using hexamethyldisilazane 48 in the presence of catalytic amounts of SBA-15-Ph-Pr-SO3H in CH2Cl2 at ambient temperature was investigated by Zareyee et al. (Scheme 13 ) [124]. Despite some promising results achieved with other catalysts (Table 3 ), the results show that some protocols took longer, some used dangerous materials with reduced isolated yields and some used non-recoverable catalysts, which clearly shows that SBA-15-Ph-Pr-SO3H should be considered one of the best choices. 3.7 Various organic transformations Acid catalysts based on MCM-41, HMS, and SBS-15 with covalently anchored propanesulfonic or benzenesulfonic acid groups were synthesized. Six samples were prepared by co-condensation of tetraethylorthosilicate with 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane or phenyltriethoxysilane in the presence of appropriate templating agents. Six other samples were made by post-synthesis modification of the parent silica materials. The samples exhibited high activities in the selective synthesis of the cyclic 1,1,3-trimethyl-3-phenylindan 52 in the dimerization of 2-phenylpropene 50 (Scheme 14 ) [123]. An analysis of selectivities (Chart 2 ) shows that catalysts can be divided into two groups: six catalyst samples give the two alkene isomers 53–54 as major products, whereas in the presence of the other six catalysts the indan derivative 52 is obtained with high selectivities. Fries rearrangement of phenyl acetate 35 over arenesulfonic modified mesostructured SBA-15 has been achieved (Scheme 15 ) [134]. The arenesulfonic acid-centers located within the structure of SBA-15 show high catalytic performance as compared to other homogeneous [135] and heterogeneous acid catalysts [136–140]. This high activity is accompanied with a remarkable stability without leaching of sulfur species during the reaction. Wang et al. found that arenesulfonic acid-functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-Ar-SO3H) was efficient in catalyzing the Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime 56 to ɛ-caprolactam 57 in the liquid phase (Scheme 16 ) [141]. The oxime conversion and selectivity to ɛ-caprolactam were found to increase with the loading of arene-SO3H groups. Later, Zhao and co-workers concluded that based on the different reaction mechanism, the chemical amount of strong acid and the catalytic amount of strong acids are necessary for the liquid phase Beckmann rearrangement [63]. Catalytic transformation of 1-adamantanol 58 was carried out over various nano-porous materials such as sulfonic-acid functionalized mesoporous silica SBA-15 (Scheme 17 ) [142]. 1-Adamantanol is isomerized to 2-adamantanol 59 by a 1,2-hydride shift, followed by an intermolecular disproportionation/dehydration of 2-adamantanol to 2-adamantanone 60. It was found that a confined microporous structure plays a major role in the formation of 2-derivatives of adamantane such as 2-adamantanol, 2-adamantyl acetate and 2-adamantanone. Liquid phase self-condensation of heptanal 61 was performed at 30 and 75°C in the presence of several heterogeneous hydrophobic acid catalysts such as perfluoroalkylsulfonic acid-functionalized PMO and perfluoroalkylsulfonic acid-grafted SBA-15 (SBA-PFSO3H) (Scheme 18 ) [143]. The results indicated that the specific activity of PMO-based catalyst was significantly higher than the SBA-15-based one. 4 Application of SBA-Pr-SO3H in two-component reactions Knoevenagel condensation of isatins 64 with malononitrile/ethyl cyanoacetate 65 in the presence of sulfonic acid functionalized silica (SBA-Pr-SO3H) has been described by Mohammadi Ziarani and co-workers (Scheme 19 ) [144]. Some of other catalysts that were tested in Knoevenagel condensation of isatin derivatives with active methylene reagents include DBU [145], neutral alumina [146], triethanolamine [147], and tris(2-hydroxy-ethyl)amine [148]. SBA-Pr-SO3H was found to be a suitable catalyst in this reaction to prepare corresponding products in high yields. In another two-component reaction, the synthesis of isoindigo derivatives 68 by green condensation of oxindole 67 with isatin derivatives 64 using SBA-Pr-SO3H as the catalyst was reported by Gholamzadeh et al. (Scheme 20 ) [149]. The synthesized compounds in this study were screened for their antimicrobial activities. Application of HCl in AcOH in this reaction was also investigated [150,151]. Efficient condensation of aromatic aldehydes 31 with oxindole 67 for the synthesis of (E)-arylidene-1,3-dihydroindole-2-ones 69 in the presence of SBA-Pr-SO3H under solvent-free conditions was successfully achieved (Scheme 21 ) [152]. Although several conditions such as KF-Al2O3 under MW irradiation [153], piperidine in EtOH [154,155], and acidic ionic liquid [(CH2)3SO3Hmim]HSO4 [156] have been reported for the synthesis of these skeletons, silica-based sulfonic acid promoted methodology has a valuable contribution to the existing processes because of short reaction time, green conditions, easy work-up procedure, and high product yields. An efficient method for the preparation of quinoxaline derivatives 72 using SBA-Pr-SO3H as a nanoporous heterogeneous acid catalyst has been reported (Scheme 22 ) [157]. Some methods are available in the literature for the synthesis of corresponding quinoxalines. A comparison of different catalysts and experimental setups is given in Table 4 . A series of quinazolinone 76 and benzamide derivatives 75 were efficiently synthesized in good to excellent yields via the reaction of 2-aminobenzamide 73 and aromatic benzoyl chlorides 74 using SBA-Pr-SO3H as a nano solid acid catalyst (Scheme 23 ) [165]. Investigations by Karimi and Zareyee have shown that mesoporous SBA-15 in which both sulfonic acid and phenyl groups are located inside the mesochannels, was the most active catalyst in the Pechmann reaction (Scheme 24 ) [166]. It was found that the mesoporous nano-reactor was much more reactive than homogeneous catalysts (p-TsOH, H2SO4), affording 90% isolated yields of the desired coumarin 78. The recovered nano-reactor was also successfully used in six successive runs and exhibited consistent activity to afford an average yield of 87% with virtually no significant loss of performance. In another study, arenesulfonic modified mesostructured SBA-15 was used as an active catalyst for Friedel Crafts acylation of anisole using acetic anhydride 32 as acylating agent (Scheme 25 ) [167]. Arenesulfonic acid-centers anchored on the pore surface of a mesostructured SBA-15 material showed a greater activity as compared to other homogeneous and heterogeneous sulfonated catalysts and even under solvent free conditions. This high activity was accompanied with a remarkable thermal stability of the acid centers, without leaching of sulfur species during the reaction. Successful Friedel Crafts acylation of anisole 79–80 and 81 in the presence of SBA-15 functionalized with perfluorosulfonic acidic Nafion resin was also investigated [168]. The recovery of the catalytic activity by regeneration of the spent catalyst by refluxing in nitric acid solution was demonstrated. It was reported that modification of the surface of the solid acid catalyst SBA-15-SO3H with the chloroalkyl groups CH2CH2Cl, has improved the selectivity in the synthesis of the phenoxy ether 83 of methyl 14-hydroxy-11-eicosenoate (methyl lesquerolate) 82 (Scheme 26 ) [169]. Selectivity improved with increased loading of the chloroalkyl group. This selectivity can be attributed to the decrease in the rate of conversion of the phenoxy ether to the Friedel Crafts adducts 84. The catalytic properties of arene sulfonic acid SBA-15 as a hybrid organic–inorganic mesoporous solid were studied using the liquid phase acetalization of heptanal 61 by 1-butanol 34 at 75°C (Scheme 27 ) [170]. It was found that large pore diameters, high hydrophobicity and strength of acid sites are the most important factors to obtain a high heptanal conversion. This reaction was also performed in the presence of periodic mesostructured organosilicas (PMOs) [143]. In another study, mesoporous silica materials, SBA-15, functionalized with strong (SO3H), moderate (PO3H2) and weak (CO2H) acid groups have been successfully prepared and applied to the alkylation of phenol 34 with tert-butanol 89 (Scheme 28 ) [171]. It was found that the activity and selectivity depended strongly on the acid strength of the catalysts and the phenol conversion was in the order of SBA-15-SO3H>SBA-15-PO3H2 >SBA-15-CO2H. SBA-15-SO3H catalyst has been found to be highly active and selective for the Prins condensation of styrene 94 with formaldehyde 95 (Scheme 29 ) [172]. Both the conversion of styrene and the selectivity to 4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane 96 were nearly 100%. It was found that presence of more number of acid sites in SBA-15-SO3H catalyst helped in achieving high yields of products. The solid acid catalyst was also tested for its reusability. No appreciable loss in activity from first cycle to subsequent cycles was noticed. Davis and co-workers reported SBA-15-containing both primary amines and sulfonic acids that exhibited a reactivity in the aldol condensation of acetone 97 with 4-nitrobenzaldehyde 31 (Scheme 30 ) [173]. Use of SBA-15 functionalized only with a sulfonic acid or amine functionality gave significantly lower levels of conversion (Table 5 , entries 2 and 3). A physical mixture of acid-functionalized SBA-15 and amine-functionalized SBA-15 showed an intermediate level of conversion that was significantly lower than the dual-functionalized acid/base catalyst (Table 5, entry 4). The support alone caused no conversion (Table 5, entry 5). Interestingly, the homogeneous analogs of the sulfonic acid and amine showed no conversion of the starting materials into either product (Table 5, entry 6). Also, the individual acid and base homogeneous analogs gave rise to very low conversions (Table 5, entries 7 and 8), much less than the acid/base bifunctional catalyst. This reaction was also reported by Guan and co-workers to investigate the catalytic activity of SO3H-SBA-15-NH2 [174]. Catalytic activity of SBA-15 materials modified with propyl sulfonic was investigated in ring-opening of epoxides 100 with different amines 101 (Scheme 31 ) [175,176]. A range of β-amino alcohols 102–103 was produced with high regioselectivity from the aminolysis of epoxides. The sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 catalysts were applied to the liquid-phase reaction of 2′-hydroxyacetophenone 55 and benzaldehyde 31 in the absence of solvent under both microwave and thermal reaction (Scheme 32 ) [177]. The catalytic results implied that the microwave reaction gave higher conversion of 2′-hydroxyacetophenone and favored for the formation of 3-benzylidine-2-phenylchroman-4-one 106 more than thermal reaction. Generally, this reaction is two steps processes. The first step is Claisen–Schmidt condensation to form 2′-hydroxy chalcone 104 and second step is subsequent cyclization to form flavanone 105. But the third new product was recently found that flavanone 105 condensed with one more benzaldehyde 31 to form substituted flavanone (3-benzylidene-2-phenylchroman-4-one) 106. The catalytic recyclability studies indicated that there was considerable conversion of 2′-hydroxyacetophenone even after fifth cycle. 5 Application of SBA-Pr-SO3H in three-component reactions Davis and co-workers investigated condensation of phenol 34 and acetone 97 to give bisphenol A 107 using homogeneous and SBA-15-immobilized sulfonic acids (Scheme 33 ) [178–180]. It was observed that inclusion of thiols into the reaction media of either type of sulfonic acid catalyst accelerates the rate of reaction and shifts the regioselectivity to favor the formation of the p,p′-bisphenol isomer (bisphenol A) 107 over the unwanted o,p′-bisphenol isomer 108. By immobilizing the thiol on the same solid as the sulfonic acid, reaction rates and regioselectivities were enhanced even further. Investigations by Cheng and co-workers has also confirmed these results [181]. The Friedel–Crafts type reaction of 2-methylfuran 109 and acetone 97 was tested in the presence of arenesulfonic modified SBA-15 material (Scheme 34 ) [182]. It was observed that the catalyst led to better yields of 2,2-[bis-(5-methylfuryl)]propane (DMP) 110 than the Nafion-H commercial resins. Furthermore, turn over numbers in the range of 1000mol of product/mol of active site were obtained in the presence of the arenesulfonic modified SBA-15 solids. The deactivation behavior of solid acid catalyst was examined by recycling the recovered dried solid in three other successive runs. The results of the two first tests were very similar; others show some decrease in the activity but the selectivity still remains as high as 90%. Facile synthesis of 1,2-disubstituted benzimidazoles 111 via condensation of 1,2-phenylenediamine 71 and aromatic aldehydes 31 using SBA-Pr-SO3H as a catalyst in green protocol was reported by Mohammadi Ziarani and co-workers (Scheme 35 ) [183]. Application of other catalysts such as silica sulfuric acid [184], [Hmim]TFA [185], [(CH2)4SO3HMIM][HSO4] [186], p-TsOH/SiO2 [187], and mesoporous mixed metal oxide nano-crystals [188] was also investigated in this reaction. In another study, several 1,2-disubstituted benzimidazoles were synthesized using SBA-15-supported poly(4-styrenesulfonyl-(perfluorobutylsulfonyl)imide) as the catalyst [189]. The protocol furnished the products in moderate yield and good selectivity in the condensation of 1,2-phenylenediamine with structurally diverse aldehydes under mild conditions. This new type of acidic composite catalyst was developed by immobilizing the homopolymer poly(4-styrenesulfonyl-(perfluorobutylsulfonyl)imide), PSFSI, onto SBA-15 silica. This solid acid catalyst, poly(4-styrenesulfonyl-(perfluorobutylsulfonyl)imide) was also highly effective for the condensation of indole 112 with structurally diverse aldehydes 31, which yielded diindolylmethane derivatives 113 (Scheme 36 ) [190]. The results demonstrated that the PSFSI/SBA-15 had good recycling stability and could be used at least five times without obvious activity loss. The catalyst was readily recyclable and eco-friendly in the synthesis of diindolylmethanes. Substituted xanthenes 115 and bis(indolyl)methanes 116 were synthesized over ordered mesoporous SBA-15 functionalized with sulfonic acid groups (Scheme 37 ) [191]. The highest catalytic activity was observed on xanthenes compared to bis(indolyl)methanes. Several different methods have been developed for the synthesis of xanthenes and bis(indolyl)methans, using reagents such as sulfamic acid [192], Amberlyst-15 [193], molecular iodine [194], alum [195], BF3·SiO2 [196], NaHSO4/SiO2 [197], and Yb(OTf)3 [198]. In spite of many methods available for the synthesis of these compounds, there is still a scope to develop simpler, recyclable and cost effective processes for these transformations. In a study by Bion and co-workers, the catalytic performances of propylsulfonic acid-functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-15-PrSO3H) and propylsulfonic acid-functionalized periodic mesoporous benzene-silica (Ph-PMO-PrSO3H) in the reaction of indole 112 with benzaldehyde 31 were compared and it was concluded that Ph-PMO-PrSO3H exhibit the higher catalytic activity [199]. A mild and efficient procedure for the synthesis of bis(4-hydroxycoumarin)methanes 118 from the condensation reaction of aldehydes 31 and 4-hydroxycoumarin 117 in the presence of SBA-Pr-SO3H was reported (Scheme 38 ) [200]. The authors also compared the efficiency of various catalysts in the synthesis of these skeletons (Table 6 ). The high yield of products and short reaction times demonstrated that SBA-Pr-SO3H acts as an efficient nano-reactor in this reaction. The condensation reaction of isatins 64 and two moles of dimedone or 1,3-cyclohexanedione 119, under solvent-free conditions, in the presence of SBA-15-Pr-SO3H resulted in the formation of spiro[indoline-3,9′-xanthene]triones 120 in much shorter reaction times and good yields (Scheme 39 ) [206]. Neutral alumina [146] and p-toluenesulfonic acid [207] were also employed for the synthesis of these skeletons. This group also reported one-pot, three-component synthesis of spirocyclic (5,6,7,8-tetrahydro-chromene)-4,3′-oxindoles 121 through the reaction of isatins 64, dimedone 119, and activated methylene reagents 65 in aqueous medium in the presence of SBA-Pr-SO3H (Scheme 40 ) [208]. Although numerous modified methods have been reported for the synthesis of spirooxindoles [209–217], SBA-Pr-SO3H was proved to be a highly effective solid acid catalyst in this reaction. Replacing dimedone with 4-hydroxycoumarin in this reaction has been also reported [218]. Spiro[indole-tetrahydro-pyrano(2,3-d)pyrimidine] derivatives 123 were synthesized in good to excellent yields by three-component reaction of isatins 64, malononitrile or cyanoacetic esters 65 and barbituric acids 122 under solvent-free conditions (Scheme 41 ) [219]. SBA-Pr-SO3H was proved to be an efficient heterogeneous nano-porous solid acid catalyst in this reaction. Further synthetic utility of the methodology has been demonstrated by replacement of malononitrile with 2-naphthol for the synthesis of spironaphthopyrano[2,3-d]pyrimidine-5,3′-indolines [220]. In another study, sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 was used as an efficient catalyst in the green one-pot synthesis of benzimidazoquinazolinones 125 and triazoloquinazolinones 127 from the reaction of aromatic aldehydes 31 with 2-aminobenzimidazole 124 (or 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole 126) and dimedone 119 (Scheme 42 ) [221]. Catalytic performance of SBA-Pr-SO3H was compared with other catalysts such as H6P2W18O62·18H2O [222] and sulfamic acid [223] and resulted in high yields of products. Rostamnia and co-workers combined ultrasonic irradiation and SBA-15/SO3H catalytic system for the synthesis of a series of 2H-indazolo[2,1-b]phthalazine-triones 129 via a three-component condensation of aldehydes 31, dimedone 119, and phthalhydrazide 128 (Scheme 43 ) [224]. The synthesis of these products has been also achieved by a similar procedure using SBA-Pr-SO3H under solvent-free conditions [225]. Replacing dimedone with malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate in this reaction was also investigated [226]. The effectiveness of combined ultrasound/nanoreactor catalytically system as an ultra-fast, waste-free and highly reusable method for the generation of α-aminophosphonates 132 via a three-component coupling has been also explored (Scheme 44 ) [224]. One-pot three-component Mannich reaction over SBA-15-Pr-SO3H under solvent-free conditions has been investigated (Scheme 45 ) [175]. While most known catalysts used for this reaction suffer from drawbacks of difficult separation after the reactions and thereby they are not reusable and some of them are corrosive and volatile and often cause the environment problems, it was found that SBA-15-Pr-SO3H is highly efficient for this reaction, yielding selectively (100%) β-amino carbonyls 134. One-pot synthesis of benzo[c]acridine derivatives 136 via the three-component condensation reaction of aromatic aldehydes 31, 1-naphtylamine 135, and dimedone 119 using sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-Pr-SO3H) as nanoporous acid catalyst under solvent-free conditions was studied (Scheme 46 ) [227]. Different conditions such as microwave irradiation on a solid support [228–230], ultrasound irradiation [231], ionic liquids [232,233], silica sulfuric acid [234], InCl3·3H2O [235], and NiCl2·6H2O/Al2O3 [236] were tested for the synthesis of 2,4,5-trisubstituted imidazoles 138. A similar catalytic behavior was obtained from SBA-Pr-SO3H in the synthesis of these skeletons. The reactions between benzil 70, various aromatic aldehydes 31, and ammonium acetate 137 were carried out under optimum condition (Scheme 47 ) [237]. The reusability of the catalyst was investigated under optimized conditions for the synthesis of the model compound. The process of recycling was completed four times and no significant decrease in activity was observed. The yields for the four runs were found to be 100%, 96%, 91%, and 82%, respectively. An efficient method for the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-d]pyrimidinediones 139 from the reaction of barbituric acid 122, malononitrile 65, and various aromatic aldehydes 31 using SBA-Pr-SO3H as a nano-catalyst was reported (Scheme 48 ) [238]. Urease inhibitory activities of the synthesized compounds were also tested and compounds with hydrophobic substitutes on the phenylene ring, showed good inhibitory activity. Some recent methods for the synthesis of corresponding products were compared in Table 7 . These methods exhibit some disadvantages such as harsh conditions, long reaction times, low yields, and effluent pollution. A simple and clean one-pot method for the preparation of pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines 141 using 6-amino uracil 140, various aromatic aldehydes 31, and malononitrile 65 in the presence of SBA-Pr-SO3H was described (Scheme 49 ) [247]. Some of synthesized compounds showed antimicrobial activities against some fungi and gram positive and negative bacteria. An efficient and environmentally benign system was developed for the one-pot three-component Strecker reaction of aldehydes 31, amines 130, and trimethylsilyl cyanide 142 under solvent-free conditions, with the use of SBA-15-Ph-Pr-SO3H [248] and SBA-15-Pr-SO3H (Scheme 50 ) [249]. 6 Application of SBA-Pr-SO3H in four-component reactions Synthesis of polyhydroquinoline derivatives 144 has been achieved via a one-pot four component reaction of aromatic aldehydes 31, dimedone 119, β-ketoesters 77, and ammonium acetate 137 under solvent free conditions using sulfonic acid functionalized nanoporous SBA-15 as solid acid catalyst (Scheme 51 ) [42]. Simultaneously application of SBA-15 sulfonic acid nanoreactor and ultrasonic irradiation was also used in this reaction [224]. In a similar approach, the catalytic activity of sulfonic acid functionalized nanoporous SBA-15 was examined in the one-pot synthesis of 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted imidazoles 145 (Scheme 52 ) [237]. 1,2,4,5-Tetrasubstituted imidazoles 145 were generally synthesized in a four-component condensation of aldehydes 31, 1,2-diketones 70, amines 130, and ammonium acetate 137. 3,4-Dihydro-2-pyridone derivatives 148 have been prepared efficiently via a one-pot four-component reaction of benzaldehyde derivatives 31, Meldrum's acid 146, methyl acetoacetate 147 and ammonium acetate 137 in the presence of sulfonic acid-functionalized ordered nanoporous SBA-15 (Scheme 53 ) [250]. After performing one reaction under solvent-free conditions, the catalyst was filtered, washed subsequently with diluted acid solution, distilled water and then acetone, dried under vacuum and reused several times. The process of recycling was completed four times and the yields were found to be 90%, 84%, 80% and 72%, respectively. An efficient diketene ring-opening synthesis of polyhydroquinoline derivatives 151 using SBA-15 sulfonic acid modified mesoporous substrate as a reusable catalyst in a one-pot four-component coupling reaction of diketene 150, alcohol 34, enamine 149, and aldehydes 31 was reported by Rostamnia and Pourhassan (Scheme 54 ). In this study, dihydropyridine derivatives 152 were also synthesized based on neat adduct of diketene 150, alcohols 34, and aldehydes 31 with ammonium acetate 137 using SBA-15/SO3H nano-reactor as catalyst (Scheme 55 ) [251]. 7 Conclusion In summary, we gave an overview on application of sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-Pr-SO3H) as an efficient acid catalyst in organic reactions. The organic–inorganic hybrid materials have received considerable attention as a consequence of their wide application potentials in versatile fields. In this regard, sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15 with high acidity has shown excellent activity in various chemical reactions especially organic synthesis. Hexagonal structure, large pore size, high surface area, great pore wall thickness, and high thermal stability are significant properties of this catalyst. SBA-Pr-SO3H was proved to be a recyclable, green, and highly effective solid acid catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous silica SBA-15 has been functionalized with sulfonic acid to create highly powerful heterogeneous solid acid catalysts (SBA-Pr-SO3H). The catalyst can be easily removed from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, recovered and reused without significant loss of activity. In this review, the catalytic activity of sulfonic acid-functionalized SBA-15 has been widely studied.
coredata.dc:title: Sulfonic acid-functionalized mesoporous silica (SBA-Pr-SO3H) as solid acid catalyst in organic reactions
